item.title: More than half of Hudson River tidal marshes were created accidentally by humans
item.description: In a new study of tidal marsh resilience to sea level rise, geologists observed that Hudson River Estuary marshes are growing upward at a rate two to three times faster than sea level rise, 'suggesting that they should be resilient to accelerated sea level rise in the future,' he says.

item.title: Identifying where to reforest after wildfire
item.description: Forest managers can now look to a newly enhanced, predictive mapping tool to learn where forests are likely to regenerate on their own and where replanting efforts may be beneficial. This study also indicates a not-so-evergreen future of fewer conifers.

item.title: Zika virus affects eye development before but not after birth
item.description: A new study finds that Zika infection during the first trimester of pregnancy can impact fetal retinal development and cause congenital ocular anomalies. The virus does not appear to affect ocular growth post-natally.

item.title: Humpback whale songs provide insight to population changes
item.description: Following reports of unusually low whale numbers that began in 2015-16, researchers examined song chorusing recorded at six sites off Maui.

item.title: Land ecosystems are becoming less efficient at absorbing CO2
item.description: Land ecosystems currently play a key role in mitigating climate change. The more carbon dioxide (CO2) plants and trees absorb during photosynthesis, the process they use to make food, the less CO2 remains trapped in the atmosphere where it can cause temperatures to rise. But scientists have identified an unsettling trend - as levels of CO2 in the atmosphere increase, 86 percent of land ecosystems globally are becoming progressively less efficient at absorbing it.

item.title: Ice sheet uncertainties could mean sea level will rise more than predicted
item.description: Sea level could rise higher than current estimates by 2100 if climate change is unchallenged, according to a new assessment.

item.title: Monkeys, like humans, persist at tasks they've already invested in
item.description: Humans are generally reluctant to give up on something they've already committed time and effort to. It's called the 'sunk costs' phenomenon, where the more resources we sink into an endeavor, the likelier we are to continue -- even if we sense it's futile. A new study shows that both capuchin monkeys and rhesus macaques are susceptible to the same behavior and that it occurs more often when the monkeys are uncertain about the outcome.

item.title: New material system to convert and generate terahertz waves developed
item.description: Terahertz light holds enormous potential for tomorrow's technologies. It might succeed 5G by enabling extremely fast mobile communications connections and wireless networks. The bottleneck in the transition from gigahertz to terahertz frequencies has been caused by insufficiently efficient sources and converters. A research team with the participation of HZDR has now developed a material system to generate terahertz pulses much more effectively than before. It is based on graphene, coated with a metallic lamellar structure.

item.title: New mechanism of force transduction in muscle cells discovered
item.description: Researchers have now discovered how the muscle-specific adhesion molecule metavinculin modulates mechanical force transduction on the molecular level.

item.title: Discovery of chromophores that emit light in the ultraviolet region when excited with visible light
item.description: Fluorescence usually entails the conversion of light at shorter wavelengths to light at longer wavelengths. Scientists have now discovered a chromophore system that goes the other way around. When excited by visible light, the fluorescent dyes emit light in the ultraviolet region. According to the study, such light upconversion systems could boost the light-dependent reactions for which efficiency is important, such as solar-powered water splitting.

item.title: Study sets baseline for sleep patterns in healthy adult dogs
item.description: A new canine sleep study could serve as a baseline for research on chronic pain and cognitive dysfunction in dogs, potentially improving detection and treatment of these conditions.

item.title: Engineers reveal molecular secrets of cephalopod powers
item.description: Researchers have revealed the structure of a reflectin variant at the molecular level, and they have demonstrated a method for mechanically controlling the hierarchical assembly and optical properties of the protein. These findings are seen as key steps in exploiting many of the potentially useful attributes of the reflectin family.

item.title: Like tentacles catching fish
item.description: Researchers decode the structure of the molecular complex that carries detoxifying enzymes in cells to the right place.

item.title: Artificial Intelligence that can run a simulation faithful to physical laws
item.description: Researchers have successfully developed technology to simulate phenomena for which the detailed mechanism or formula are unexplained. They did this by using AI to create a model, which is faithful to the laws of physics, from observational data. This technology will hopefully enable these kinds of phenomena (e.g. wave motion and fracture mechanics) to be more accurately predicted by computer simulations.

item.title: Compressive fluctuations heat ions in space plasma
item.description: New simulations carried out in part on the ATERUI II supercomputer in Japan have found that the reason ions exist at higher temperatures than electrons in space plasma is because they are better able to absorb energy from compressive turbulent fluctuations in the plasma. These finding have important implications for understanding observations of various astronomical objects such as the images of the accretion disk and shadow of the M87 supermassive black hole.

item.title: Social holidays improve overall well-being
item.description: Social holidays improve holiday makers' overall satisfaction with life, as well as satisfaction with the quantity and quality of their leisure time, and social life, according to a new study. The study analyzed the effect of social holidays on holiday makers' subjective well-being and experience of inclusion.

item.title: Individuals with high ADHD-traits are more vulnerable to insomnia
item.description: Individuals with high ADHD-traits that do not meet the criteria for a diagnosis are less able to perform tasks involving attentional regulation or emotional control after a sleepless night than individuals with low ADHD-traits, a new study reports.

item.title: The 'crazy beast' that lived among the dinosaurs
item.description: New research describes a bizarre 66 million-year-old mammal that provides profound new insights into the evolutionary history of mammals from the southern supercontinent Gondwana - recognized today as Africa, South America, Australia, Antarctica, the Indian subcontinent, and the Arabian Peninsula.

item.title: Machine intelligence accelerates research into mapping brains
item.description: Scientists have used machine intelligence to improve the accuracy and reliability of a powerful brain-mapping technique, a new study reports. Their development gives researchers more confidence in using the technique to untangle the human brain's wiring and to better understand the changes in this wiring that accompany neurological or mental disorders such as Parkinson's or Alzheimer's disease.

item.title: Cell atlas of tropical disease parasite may hold key to new treatments
item.description: The first cell atlas of an important life stage of Schistosoma mansoni, a parasitic worm that poses a risk to hundreds of millions of people each year, has been developed.

item.title: Fibrous protein finding may lead to improved bioprinting, tissue engineering
item.description: Fibrous proteins such as collagen and fibrinogen form a thin solid layer on the surface of an aqueous solution similar to the 'skin' that forms on warm milk, according to a team of Penn State Researchers, who believe this finding could lead to more efficient bioprinting and tissue engineering.

item.title: Growing human organs for transplantation with new proof-of-concept
item.description: With the number of people who suffer from organ failures and the growing need for available organs for transplant, finding a new way to provide organs and therapeutic options to transplant patients is a critical need. In a new article, researchers show for the first time that newly established stem cells from pigs could provide a solution, laying the groundwork for growing transplantable human organs.

item.title: How long's too long? Effects of crosslinker length on anion-exchange membrane fuel cells
item.description: Anion exchange membrane (AEM) fuel cells (AEMFCs), which produce electricity using hydrogen, are considered an alternative to currently used proton exchange membrane fuel cells. However, AEMs have problems with stability in alkaline conditions, which can be overcome by crosslinking -- but effects of crosslinker length on AEMFC performance are not well understood. Now, scientists have elucidated such effects for oxygen-containing crosslinkers and, using an optimally long crosslinker, produced a novel AEMFC with greater performance.

item.title: How climate change is disrupting ecosystems
item.description: When it gets warmer, organisms rise higher from the lowlands. Researchers investigated what could happen to plant communities on alpine grasslands if grasshoppers from lower elevations settled there.

item.title: COVID-19 virus enters the brain, research strongly suggests
item.description: The SARS-CoV-2 virus, like many viruses before it, is bad news for the brain. In a new study, researchers found that the spike protein, often depicted as the red arms of the virus, can cross the blood-brain barrier in mice. The spike proteins alone can cause brain fog. Since the spike protein enters the brain, the virus also is likely to cross into the brain.

item.title: Oceans without oxygen
item.description: With no dissolved oxygen to sustain animals or plants, ocean anoxic zones are areas where only microbes suited to the environment can live.

item.title: Protein linked to progressive lung scarring in scleroderma patients
item.description: Osteopontin is discovered as the culprit behind systemic sclerosis patients' main cause of death: lung fibrosis. However, a repurposed immunosuppressive drug may combat the pro-inflammatory protein.

item.title: Green revolution saved over 100 million infant lives in developing world
item.description: New research shows that since modern crop varieties were introduced in the developing world starting in 1961, they have substantially reduced infant mortality, especially for male babies and among poor households.

item.title: Study in mice shows genes may be altered through drug repurposing
item.description: Researchers screened drugs that can enhance the PAX6 gene and found MEK inhibitors can stimulate PAX6 expression in the eye. They tested this drug in newborn PAX6 deficient mice and found that either topical or oral administration of the drug enhanced PAX6 and partially normalized their eye development. Mice treated with topical MEK inhibitor had clearer corneas (less scarring) and could see better.

item.title: Machine learning boosts the search for 'superhard' materials
item.description: Superhard materials are in high demand in industry, from energy production to aerospace, but finding suitable new materials has largely been a matter of trial and error based on classical materials such as diamonds. Now researchers have reported a machine learning model that can accurately predict the hardness of new materials, allowing scientists to more readily find compounds suitable for use in a variety of applications.

item.title: Can white dwarfs help solve the cosmological lithium problem?
item.description: For the first time, lithium has been identified and measured in the atmosphere of a white dwarf. The finding provides clues for what's become of the lithium expected from the Big Bang.

item.title: Scientists set a path for field trials of gene drive organisms
item.description: Setting a course for responsible testing of powerful gene drive technology, a multidisciplinary coalition of gene drive organism developers, ecologists and conservation biologists has joined experts in social science, ethics and policy in a policy article published in Science. The group describes core commitments that ensure that gene drive organism field trials are safely implemented, transparent, publicly accountable and scientifically, politically and socially robust.

item.title: Taking greenhouse gas analysis on the road, er, rails
item.description: Since 2014, there have been research-grade suites of air quality instruments installed and maintained on light rail trains that move throughout the Salt Lake Valley every day. These mobile sensors, researchers estimate in a new study, cover the same area as 30 stationary sensors, providing the Salt Lake Valley with a highly cost-effective way to monitor its greenhouse emissions and fill in gaps in emissions estimates.

item.title: Scientists create entangled photons 100 times more efficiently than previously possible
item.description: Super-fast quantum computers and communication devices could revolutionize countless aspects of our lives -- but first, researchers need a fast, efficient source of the entangled pairs of photons such systems use to transmit and manipulate information. Researchers have done just that, not only creating a chip-based photon source 100 times more efficient that previously possible, but bringing massive quantum device integration within reach.

item.title: Can water saving traits help wine survive climate change?
item.description: Climate change is expected to make many grape-growing regions too hot and dry to produce high-quality wine from traditional varieties. But scientists have found that wine grape varieties from regions that are more prone to stress have traits that could help them cope with climate change.

item.title: Polariton interactions: Light matters
item.description: Why do 2D exciton-polaritons interact? This intriguing quasiparticle, which is part light (photon), and part matter (exciton), doesn't behave as predicted: continuing to interact with other particles when confined to two dimensions in extremely cold conditions. A new study finds the answer lies in the 'light-like' characteristics of these quasiparticles, with importance for future applications such as ultra-low energy electronics.

item.title: Exercise for low back pain beneficial but no one agrees on why
item.description: A new evidence review has found there is still no consensus between researchers about why exercise works for low back pain patients - despite decades of studies on the topic.

item.title: Method finds hidden warning signals in measurements collected over time
item.description: Researchers have developed a deep learning-based algorithm to detect anomalies in time series data. The technology could provide advance warning of potential failures in systems ranging from satellites to computer data centers.

item.title: Can mammogram screening be more effective?
item.description: Economists have identified an important challenge in designing age-related guidelines for when to start breast cancer screenings: Women who start getting mammograms at age 40 may be healthier than the population of 40-year-old women as a whole, with a lower incidence of breast cancer at that age.

item.title: Study tracks elephant tusks from 16th century shipwreck
item.description: In 1533, the Bom Jesus - a Portuguese trading vessel carrying 40 tons of cargo including gold, silver, copper and more than 100 elephant tusks - sank off the coast of Africa near present-day Namibia. The wreck was found in 2008, and scientists say they now have determined the source of much of the ivory recovered from the ship.

item.title: Territorial red squirrels live longer when they're friendly with their neighbors
item.description: Researchers found that red squirrels in the Yukon have a greater chance of survival when living near neighbors. These fitness benefits depended on familiarity, or how long the same squirrels lived next to each other. These benefits were more pronounced in older squirrels, whom the data suggested could sharply offset the effects of aging by maintaining all of their neighbors from one year to the next.

item.title: Ultra-thin designer materials unlock quantum phenomena
item.description: New research has measured highly sought-after Majorana quantum states.

item.title: Seeking to avoid 'full lockdown,' cells monitor ribosome collisions
item.description: New research shows that cells monitor for ribosome collisions to determine the severity of the problem and how best to respond when things start to go awry.

item.title: Cataract surgery in infancy increases glaucoma risk
item.description: Children who undergo cataract surgery as infants have a 22% risk of glaucoma 10 years later, whether or not they receive an intraocular lens implant.

item.title: Change in global precipitation patterns as a result of climate change
item.description: Earth's climate system is largely determined by the differences in temperature between the tropics and the poles. Global warming is likely to cause global atmospheric circulation to change and progressively revert to a situation similar to that of 5,000 to 10,000 years ago.

item.title: A new means of neuronal communication discovered in the human brain
item.description: An international research group has discovered in the human brain a new functional coupling mechanism between neurons, which may serve as a communication channel between brain regions.

item.title: Fertilizer runoff in streams and rivers can have cascading effects, analysis shows
item.description: Fertilizer pollution can have significant ripple effects in the food webs of streams and rivers, according to a new analysis of global data.

item.title: Weddell sea: Whale song reveals behavioral patterns
item.description: Scientists have now used permanently installed underwater microphones, which have been recording for the past nine years, to successfully gather and analyze whale observation data from the Weddell Sea. The AWI's underwater recordings confirm: Minke whales prefer the shelter of sea ice, while humpback whales avoid it.

item.title: Artificial intelligence classifies supernova explosions with unprecedented accuracy
item.description: Scientists have trained machine learning software to classify supernovae without the traditional use of spectra. The project -- the first to use real supernovae data to inform its artificial intelligence -- is 82% accurate. Currently, scientists take spectra of 10-percent of the ~10,000 supernovae discovered each year. When the Rubin Observatory goes online, only 0.1-percent of the expected supernovae discoveries will be further studied without the new software.

item.title: Researchers discover brain area crucial for recognizing visual events
item.description: Researchers report that a brain region in the superior temporal sulcus (fSTS) is crucial for processing and making decisions about visual information.

item.title: Errant DNA boosts immunotherapy effectiveness
item.description: DNA that ends up where it doesn't belong in cancer cells can unleash an immune response that makes tumors more susceptible to immunotherapy, the results of two new studies indicate. The findings suggest that delivering radiation - which triggers DNA release from cells - before immunotherapy could be an effective way to fight cancers that are challenging to treat.

item.title: Researchers discover brain pattern that could improve mental health disorder diagnosis
item.description: A pattern in how the brain breaks down tryptophan, a common amino acid consumed through food, was discovered.

item.title: What's up, Skip? Kangaroos really can 'talk' to us, study finds
item.description: Animals that have never been domesticated, such as kangaroos, can intentionally communicate with humans, challenging the notion that this behavior is usually restricted to domesticated animals like dogs, horses or goats, a new study has found.

item.title: Talking to kids about weight: What the internet says and why researchers are wary
item.description: Researchers systematically reviewed numerous independently published guidelines for having conversations with children about weight status to analyze their content, consistency, actionability and scientific support. They recommend future guidelines unify their messages and be better supported by scholarly data.

item.title: Crops near Chernobyl still contaminated
item.description: Crops grown near Chernobyl are still contaminated due to the 1986 nuclear accident, new research shows.

item.title: Computational model reveals how the brain manages short-term memories
item.description: Scientists have developed a new computational model showing how the brain maintains information short-term using specific types of neurons. Their findings could help shed light on why working memory is impaired in a broad range of neuropsychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia, as well as in normal aging.

item.title: Antifungal drug improves key cystic fibrosis biomarkers in clinical study
item.description: A drug widely used to treat fungal infections improved key biomarkers in lung tissue cultures as well as in the noses of patients with cystic fibrosis, a clinical study found.

item.title: Optogenetic method can reveal how gut microbes affect longevity
item.description: Optogenetics offers a direct way to manipulate gut bacterial metabolism in a temporally, quantitatively and spatially controlled manner and enhance host fitness.

item.title: Transforming clean energy technology
item.description: A team of researchers has developed a new method of harnessing solar energy, moving us closer to a clean energy future.

item.title: More West Nile virus-infected mosquitoes in lower-income areas of Baltimore
item.description: Researchers found higher rates of West Nile virus-infected mosquitoes in lower-income neighborhoods in urban areas of Baltimore, Maryland. This preliminary data provides another piece of the puzzle pointing to higher risk of mosquito-transmitted diseases in these neighborhoods already struggling with environmental injustices and poorer health outcomes.

item.title: Colour me beautiful: US rivers try a new hue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 December 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-03592-8

In the past 35 years, some US waterways have become greener and others yellower, providing clues to ecosystem health.
item.dc:title: Colour me beautiful: US rivers try a new hue

Veteran environmental regulator Michael Regan will lead the Environmental Protection Agency, joining an experienced team of climate appointees.

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Targeted wetland restoration could greatly reduce nitrogen pollution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 December 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-03515-7

Wetlands remove nitrate pollution from water effectively. An analysis shows that this effect is constrained in the United States by the distribution of wetlands, and could be increased by targeting wetland restoration to nitrate sources.
item.dc:title: Targeted wetland restoration could greatly reduce nitrogen pollution
item.dc:creator: Jacques C. Finlay

item.content:encoded:

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03043-4

Although progress in the coverage of routine measles vaccination in children in low- and middle-income countries was made during 2000–2019, many countries remain far from the goal of 80% coverage in all districts by 2019.
item.dc:title: Mapping routine measles vaccination in low- and middle-income countries

item.title: Small-molecule inhibitors of human mitochondrial DNA transcription
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03048-z

Inhibitors of mitochondrial transcription that target human mitochondrial RNA polymerase provide a chemical biology tool for studying the role of mitochondrial DNA expression in a wide range of pathologies.
item.dc:title: Small-molecule inhibitors of human mitochondrial DNA transcription

item.title: Fat1 deletion promotes hybrid EMT state, tumour stemness and metastasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03046-1

In mouse and human squamous cell carcinoma, loss of function of FAT1 promotes tumour initiation, malignant progression and metastasis through the activation of a hybrid epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition phenotype.
item.dc:title: Fat1 deletion promotes hybrid EMT state, tumour stemness and metastasis

item.title: Entanglement on an optical atomic-clock transition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3006-1

A many-atom state of trapped 171Yb atoms that are entangled on an optical atomic-clock transition overcomes the standard quantum limit, providing a proof-of-principle demonstration towards entanglement-based optical atomic clocks.
item.dc:title: Entanglement on an optical atomic-clock transition

item.title: Self-assembly of a layered two-dimensional molecularly woven fabric
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3019-9

An anion and metal ion template is used to form woven polymer patches that are joined together by polymerization into a fully woven, two-dimensional, molecular patchwork.
item.dc:title: Self-assembly of a layered two-dimensional molecularly woven fabric

item.title: Tuning the Chern number in quantum anomalous Hall insulators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3020-3

The number of edge channels in quantum anomalous Hall insulators is controlled by varying either the magnetic dopant concentration or the interior spacer layer thickness, yielding Chern numbers up to 5.
item.dc:title: Tuning the Chern number in quantum anomalous Hall insulators

item.title: Cortical response selectivity derives from strength in numbers of synapses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03044-3

Live neuron imaging and electron microscopy reconstruction shows that the selectivity of cortical neuron responses to visual stimuli arises from the total number of synapses activated rather than being dominated by a small number of strong synaptic inputs.
item.dc:title: Cortical response selectivity derives from strength in numbers of synapses
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Scholl
Connon I. Thomas
Melissa A. Ryan
Naomi Kamasawa
David Fitzpatrick

item.title: Half-minute-scale atomic coherence and high relative stability in a tweezer clock
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3009-y

A tweezer clock containing about 150 88Sr atoms achieves trapping and optical excited-state lifetimes exceeding 40 seconds, and shows relative fractional frequency stability similar to that of leading atomic clocks.
item.dc:title: Half-minute-scale atomic coherence and high relative stability in a tweezer clock

Adam M. Kaufman

item.title: Sorting nexin 5 mediates virus-induced autophagy and immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03056-z

Genome-wide siRNA screens identify an essential function for sorting nexin 5 in virus-induced autophagy and immunity mediated via class III phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase complex 1.
item.dc:title: Sorting nexin 5 mediates virus-induced autophagy and immunity

item.title: Antidepressant actions of ketamine engage cell-specific translation via eIF4E
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03047-0

The antidepressant-like effects of ketamine in mice depend on the expression of specific eIF4E-binding proteins in excitatory and inhibitory neurons.
item.dc:title: Antidepressant actions of ketamine engage cell-specific translation via eIF4E

item.title: Anti-tumour immunity induces aberrant peptide presentation in melanoma
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03054-1

Tryptophan depletion in melanoma cells after prolonged treatment with interferon-? (IFN?) results in ribosomal frameshifting and the production of aberrant peptides that can be presented to T cells and induce an immune response.
item.dc:title: Anti-tumour immunity induces aberrant peptide presentation in melanoma

item.title: Maximizing US nitrate removal through wetland protection and restoration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03042-5

Analysis of US continental wetland inventory data combined with model simulations indicate that a spatially targeted 10% increase in wetland area could double wetland nitrogen removal.
item.dc:title: Maximizing US nitrate removal through wetland protection and restoration
item.dc:creator: F. Y. Cheng

item.title: Topological superconductivity in a van der Waals heterostructure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2989-y

A van der Waals structure based on a two-dimensional magnet and layered superconductor offers a potential system in which topological superconductivity could be easily tuned and integrated into devices.
item.dc:title: Topological superconductivity in a van der Waals heterostructure

item.title: More than one million barriers fragment Europe’s rivers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3005-2

Validated barrier inventories and modelling indicate that Europe’s rivers are fragmented by more than one million barriers, such as dams, weirs and fords, causing major impacts on biodiversity.
item.dc:title: More than one million barriers fragment Europe’s rivers

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3033-y

Spin transport far from equilibrium is studied in a Heisenberg model with adjustable anisotropy realized with coupled ultracold 7Li atoms, and different dynamical regimes are found for positive and negative anisotropies.

item.title: European rivers are fragmented by many more barriers than had been recorded
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-03440-9

An atlas of European river barriers has been made, by curating and correcting existing records, and by surveying 2,700 kilometres of waterways. It reveals that rivers are fragmented by an amazing number of obstructions.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-03535-3

Misoprostol can prevent and treat postpartum haemorrhage. But because it can also cause abortions, availability of the cheap medication is often tightly restricted.

item.content:encoded:

An analysis of more than 6 million YouTube videos finds that people around the world make similar facial expressions in similar social contexts. The study brings data science to the debate about the universality of emotion categories.

item.title: Precise mapping reveals gaps in global measles vaccination coverage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/d41586-020-03391-1

Precise maps of routine first-dose measles vaccinations show slowing progress around the world between 2010 and 2019, and large gaps in coverage in many places. Many countries are unlikely to achieve global 2020 coverage targets.

item.title: Apollo 8: Earthrise
item.description: This iconic picture shows Earth peeking out from beyond the lunar surface as the first crewed spacecraft circumnavigated the Moon.

item.title: Stellar Snowflake Cluster
item.description: The newly revealed infant stars appear as pink and red specks toward the center and appear to have formed in regularly spaced intervals along linear structures.

item.title: Stellar Jewel Box
item.description: Thousands of sparkling young stars are nestled within the giant nebula NGC 3603, one of the most massive young star clusters in the Milky Way Galaxy. NGC 3603, a prominent star-forming region in the Carina spiral arm of the Milky Way about 20,000 light-years away, reveals stages in the life cycle of stars.

item.title: A Great Conjunction Draws Near
item.description: The Moon, left, Saturn, upper right, and Jupiter, lower right, are seen after sunset with the Washington Monument, Thurs. Dec. 17, 2020, in Washington.

item.title: Entering the Martian Atmosphere with the Perseverance Rover
item.description: With its heat shield facing the planet, NASA’s Perseverance rover begins its descent through the Martian atmosphere in this illustration.

item.title: Starry, Starry Night
item.description: The Hubble Space Telescope captured a crowd of stars that looks rather like a stadium darkened before a show, lit only by the flashbulbs of the audience's cameras.

item.title: Quasars Rip Across Galaxies Like Tsunamis
item.description: Using the unique capabilities of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, a team of astronomers has discovered the most energetic outflows ever witnessed in the universe.

item.title: Educational CubeSats to Launch on Virgin Orbit’s LauncherOne Rocket
item.description: Ten NASA-sponsored CubeSats are preparing to fly on the agency’s next Educational Launch of Nanosatellites (ELaNa) mission, making this the first payload carried by Virgin Orbit’s LauncherOne rocket.

item.title: 50 Years of Research Using Langley's 14 by-22-Foot Subsonic Wind Tunnel
item.description: Dec. 11, 2020, marks the 50th anniversary of NASA’s Langley Research Center’s 14x22 Subsonic Wind Tunnel.

item.title: Introducing the Artemis Astronauts
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence introduces NASA astronauts during a meeting of the National Space Council on Dec. 9, 2020.

item.title: 3D Printed Rocket Parts and the Future of Spacecraft
item.description: Future lunar landers might come equipped with 3D printed rocket engine parts that help bring down overall manufacturing costs and reduce production time.

item.title: NASA, Boeing Complete Series of Starliner Parachute Tests
item.description: NASA and Boeing have completed Starliner’s last parachute balloon-drop test designed to strengthen the spacecraft’s landing system ahead of crewed flights.

item.title: Seeing the Station From Earth
item.description: The International Space Station is seen in this 13 second exposure as it flies over Arlington, Virginia, Sunday, Dec. 6, 2020.

item.title: Relaxing Inside the Space Station's Window to the World
item.description: JAXA and Expedition 64 astronaut Soichi Noguchi relaxes at the end of the work day inside the seven-windowed cupola on the International Space Station.

item.title: Awakening Newborn Stars
item.description: Lying inside our home galaxy, the Milky Way, this Herbig–Haro object is a turbulent birthing ground for new stars in a region known as the Orion B molecular cloud complex, located 1,350 light-years away.

item.title: Earth May Be Surrounded by Hairy Dark Matter
item.description: This illustration shows Earth surrounded by theoretical filaments of dark matter called "hairs."

item.title: Carol Harrison: Seeing the Beauty in All Things
item.description: Carol Carol "Bird Song" Harrison is a a quality assurance specialist (QAS) working in the Mission Assurance Branch at NASA's Langley Research Center.

item.title: It's Black Hole Friday!
item.description: What is a black hole? A black hole is an astronomical object with a gravitational pull so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape it.

item.title: Kenneth Attocknie: Fulfilling a Dream
item.description: Kenneth Attocknie has worked as an engineer for more than two decades at NASA's Johnson Space Center.

item.title: Artemis I Stacks Up
item.description: The first of 10 pieces of the twin Space Launch System (SLS) rocket boosters for NASA’s Artemis I mission was placed on the mobile launcher Saturday, Nov. 21, 2020.

item.title: Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich Launches to Monitor Global Ocean
item.description: The SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich spacecraft lifts off from Space Launch Complex 4 at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, Nov. 21, 2020.

item.title: Hubble Captures Cosmic Cinnamon Bun
item.description: Observed with the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, the faint galaxy featured in this image is known as UGC 12588.

item.title: Marcellus Proctor: Bring a Unique Perspective
item.description: Marcellus Proctor is an enrolled member of the Piscataway-Conoy Nation and the Assistant Chief in the Electrical Engineering Division at NASA Goddard .

item.title: SpaceX Crew Dragon Approaches Space Station
item.description: The SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft is pictured approaching the International Space Station for a docking.

item.title: Hubble Spies Galaxy through Cosmic Lens
item.description: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image features the galaxy LRG-3-817, also known as SDSS J090122.37+181432.3.

item.title: Crew-1 Launches on Historic Journey
item.description: SpaceX's Falcon 9 launches Crew-1 to the space station on Sunday, Nov. 15, 2020.

item.title: Lauren Denson: Jumping for Joy
item.description: With a degree in computer engineering and computer science from the University of Southern California, Lauren Denson is now an quality engineer and supervisor at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

item.title: Hubble Catches a Cosmic Cascade
item.description: The galaxy UGCA 193, seen here by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, is a galaxy in the constellation of Sextans (The Sextant).

item.title: SpaceX Falcon 9 Rolls Out for Saturday Launch
item.description: Launch is scheduled for 7:49 p.m. EST on Saturday, Nov. 14, 2020.

item.title: Astronauts Launching on NASA's SpaceX Crew-1 Mission Arrive at Kennedy Space Center
item.description: NASA astronauts Shannon Walker, left, Victor Glover, second from left, Mike Hopkins, second from right, and Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) astronaut Soichi Noguchi, right, are seen as they speak to members of the media after arriving at the Launch and Landing Facility at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center ahead of SpaceX’s Crew-1 mission.

item.title: Preparing the Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich Satellite for Launch
item.description: The Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich ocean-monitoring satellite is being encapsulated in the SpaceX Falcon 9 payload fairing.

item.title: Aerospace Engineer Joseph Connolly
item.description: Joseph Connolly is an aerospace engineer at NASA's Glenn Research Center.

item.title: Our Sun's Glint Beams Off San Francisco
item.description: The crew aboard the International Space Station snapped this image of the Earth's limb, or horizon, with the Sun's glint beaming off the U.S. West Coast.

item.title: Raquel Redhouse: Small Spacecraft Systems Virtual Institute Technical Manager
item.description: Raquel Redhouse is member of the Navajo (Diné) Nation, a mother and an engineer.

item.title: Celebrating 20 Years on Station: Expedition 1
item.description: This is the official portrait of the Expedition 1 crew, the first humans to live aboard the International Space Station.

item.title: Night Aboard the Space Station
item.description: Night aboard the International Space Station can seemingly look like every spooky sci-fi movie you've ever seen.

item.title: Our Halloween Sun
item.description: Active regions on the sun combined to look something like a jack-o-lantern’s face on Oct. 8, 2014.

item.title: 'Sprites' Frolic in Jupiter's Atmosphere
item.description: The lightning phenomenon known as a sprite depicted at Jupiter in this illustration.

item.title: NASA Astronaut Kate Rubins Casts Her Vote from Space
item.description: NASA astronaut Kate Rubins points to the International Space Station's "voting booth" where she cast her vote from space this month.

item.title: Jezero Crater Was a Lake in Mars' Ancient Past
item.description: This illustration shows Jezero Crater — the landing site of the Mars 2020 Perseverance rover.

item.title: Hubble Views a Galactic Waterfall
item.description: In this spectacular image captured by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, the galaxy NGC 2799 (on the left) is seemingly being pulled into the center of the galaxy NGC 2798 (on the right).

item.title: Studying Aircraft Noise
item.description: An array of 960 microphones is seen here off the end of runway 11 at Boeing’s research facility near Glasgow, Montana.

item.title: Touching Down on Asteroid Bennu
item.description: On Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2020, NASA’s OSIRIS-REx sample collection mission performed a successful “Touch-And-Go” (TAG) maneuver.

item.title: Neutron Stars Create Gold and Platinum in Their Wake
item.description: This illustration shows the hot, dense, expanding cloud of debris stripped from neutron stars just before they collided.

item.title: Orion’s Recently Installed Solar Array Wings
item.description: Two of Orion’s four recently installed solar array wings are exposed and surrounded by the panels that will protect it during launch and ascent.

item.title: Hubble Snaps a Special Stellar Nursery
item.description: This Hubble image shows a special class of star-forming nursery known as Free-floating Evaporating Gaseous Globules. Called frEGGs for short, these dark compact globules of dust and gas can give birth to low-mass stars.

item.title: Cliffs in Ancient Ice on Mars
item.description: Scientists have come to realize that, just below the surface, about one third of Mars is covered in ice.

item.title: NASA Astronaut Kate Rubins Prepares for Launch to Space Station
item.description: NASA astronaut Kate Rubins is seen as she has her Russian Sokol suit pressure checked as she and fellow crewmates prepare for their Soyuz launch to the International Space Station.

item.title: The Ghost Nebula
item.description: ?Powerful gushers of energy from seething stars can sculpt eerie-looking figures with long flowing veils of gas and dust.

item.title: The Iris Nebula
item.description: The beautiful, blushing Iris Nebula is unique amongst its counterparts.

item.title: Thumbs Up From Out of This World
item.description: ASA spacewalkers (from left) Bob Behnken and Chris Cassidy give a thumbs up during a spacewalk to install hardware and upgrade International Space Station systems.

item.title: Grappling With the Future
item.description: The tip of the Canadarm2 robotic arm, also formally known as the Latching End Effector, is pictured as the International Space Station soared over the South Pacific Ocean .

item.title: Overcoming Hurricanes and Earthquakes to Get an Experiment to the Space Station
item.description: Camila Morales-Navas conducts final preparations on the Electrochemical Ammonia Removal system prior to parabolic flight testing.

item.title: Antares Rocket Launches to the Space Station
item.description: An Northrop Grumman Antares rocket, with the company’s Cygnus spacecraft aboard, launches at 9:16 p.m. EDT, Friday, October 2, 2020, from t NASA's Wallops Flight Facility in Virginia.

item.title: Hubble Captures Galactic Glamour Shot
item.description: This stunning image by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope features the spiral galaxy NGC 5643 in the constellation of Lupus (the Wolf). NGC 5643 is about 60 million light-years away from Earth.

item.title: Satellite Captures Active Fires in the Western U.S.
item.description: Our Aqua satellite captured this composite visible and infrared image on Sep. 29, 2020, which shows that fires and smoke continue to dominate the landscape of the western U.S.

item.title: Retroreflectors: From Apollo to Mars
item.description: When Apollo 11 landed on the Moon, the crew brought devices with them called retroreflectors, which are essentially small arrays of mirrors.

item.title: Astronaut Serena M. Auñón-Chancellor Examines Her Eyes in Space
item.description: Astronaut Serena Auñón-Chancellor examines her eye with a Fundoscope aboard the International Space Station with remote support from doctors on the ground.

item.title: Soyuz MS-16 Spacecraft Docked to the Space Station
item.description: Pictured is the Soyuz MS-16 crew ship, currently docked to the International Space Station's Poisk module.

item.title: Hubble Shoots the Moon
item.description: This image from 1991 shows Earth's Moon, with its dark basaltic mare, clearly visible in great detail.
